They didnâ€™t. Initially Heike Kamerlingh Onnes Delft and Kes (2010) and others were just interested in cryogenics.
Once they achieved liquid Helium, they asked why note study conductive metals at these temperatures.
In 1911 Kamerlingh Onnes started with elemental Mercury, ðŸ’¥ the field of superconductivity (SC) was born.

Physcist focused on measurement of other elemental solides and a theory.
Observation of SC in Nb is really what begun technological use.

title: Crash Course in Materials Science of Superconductors
text:
Some Comments






Important


These are working notes, so there are bound to be errors. Please keep this in mind while going through the notes. Feel free to email me if you want to provide corrections.









Note


Much of the notes derived from various sources, please checkout the references.









Tip


If you prefer to view this in a report format, you can download a formatted PDF of this presentation here.

title: Crash Course in Materials Science of Superconductors
text:
Whats all the fuss



Why did anyone care to begin with?

They didnâ€™t. Initially Heike Kamerlingh Onnes1 and others were just interested in cryogenics.
Once they achieved liquid Helium, they asked why note study conductive metals at these temperatures.
In 1911 Kamerlingh Onnes started with elemental Mercury, ðŸ’¥ the field of superconductivity (SC) was born.

Physcist focused on measurement of other elemental solides and a theory.
Observation of SC in Nb is really what begun technological use.





FigureÂ 1: Original plot of Hg transition temperature to SC phase1






SC: Superconductivity Nb: Niobium
